I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) requested that the Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  provide  policy  and  advisory  technical  assistance  (TA)  for  the 
development  of  a  Strategy  for  Liaoning  North  Yellow  Sea  Regional  Cooperation  and 
Development.1  Following a fact-finding mission in July 2015, the government and ADB reached 
an understanding on the impact, outcome, outputs, implementation arrangements, costs and 
financial arrangements, and terms of reference for consulting services for the TA. The design 
and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.2   
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The PRC is deepening its integration with the global economy. ADB has provided prior 
technical assistance to this effort, as reflected in its inputs to the preparation of the PRC’s 13th 
Five  Year  Plan,  2016–2020.  The  PRC’s  globalization  strategy,  issued  in  March  2015, 
recognizes the importance of promoting regional cooperation and integration, both internally and 
as part of this outward-focused policy.3 It is also a focus area of the policy measures introduced 
by the government’s revitalization strategy for the Northeast PRC, as elaborated in a 2014 State 
Council opinion.4  
 
3.  Subregional  engagement  is  being  facilitated  through  the  participation  of  the  PRC’s 
northeastern  provinces in  the Greater Tumen  Initiative’s  Northeast  Asia  Local  Cooperation 
Committee.5 The objective of the committee is to facilitate practical cooperation among local 
governments in Northeast Asia regarding their common concerns for regional development, and 
to strengthen policy coordination between local and central governments.6 There is, however, 
currently no regional cooperation framework guiding these processes and developments. 
 
4.  Liaoning Province is well positioned to participate in the implementation of the PRC’s 
globalization strategy. It is the only coastal province in the Northeast PRC, and is a transport 
hub between the northeastern and central regions, and a key regional portal to the Eurasian 
Continental Bridge. The connection to Europe has recently been strengthened with the opening 
of the Yingkou–Manzhouli–Europe Railway. In addition, Dalian Jinpu New Zone is a strategic 
connection for contact and cooperation between the PRC and the rest of  Northeast Asia, 
because of the province’s position on the North Yellow Sea. The Dalian Jinpu New Zone 
facilitates communication among the PRC, Japan, the Republic of Korea, Mongolia, and Russia, 
and serves to explore new cooperation mechanisms.  
 
5.  The  Liaoning  provincial  government  and  the  Liaoning  Provincial  Committee  of  the 
Communist Party of China are examining ways to strengthen policies and guidance aimed at 
deepening participation in the PRC’s globalization strategy. This TA proposes to help lay the

development initiatives, the TA will support the development of a needs assessment, baseline 
strategy, and implementation plan for Liaoning Province’s regional cooperation and integration 
priorities.  It  will  also  deliver  targeted  research  on  key  bottlenecks  to  deepening  regional 
integration,  and  study  the  domestic  and  international  experience  with  designing  and 
implementing regional cooperation programs. To help Liaoning Province position itself to better 
benefit from the recently concluded economic partnership agreement between Mongolia and 
Japan, the research will explore ways to increase Liaoning’s attractiveness as a transit corridor 
and to support an anticipated increase in trade between Japan and Mongolia.  
 
6.  These advisory products will guide the Liaoning Provincial Department of Finance (DOF) 
and other agencies involved in regional cooperation initiatives. They can serve as a model for 
easy and rapid replication by the PRC’s other northeastern provinces.  
 
III.  THE POLICY AND ADVISORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  The TA impact is aligned with the government’s goals of augmenting cooperation among 
internal subregions of Northeast PRC, and promoting regional cooperation in Northeast Asia. 
The outcome will be adoption by Liaoning Province of a regional cooperation and integration 
(RCI) development strategy and implementation action plan. Achievement will be measured by 
the submission for approval—by the Liaoning provincial government— of an RCI development 
strategy and action plan.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8.  The impact and outcome of the TA will be achieved through the delivery of the following 
outputs: 
(i)  Status  report  and  impact  assessment  produced  on  implementation  of 
earlier  regional  development  programs  in  Liaoning  Province. These  will 
analyze the extent to which prior initiatives have increased the competitiveness 
of Liaoning’s economy, expanded trade (including transit traffic), and attracted 
inward investment. Regional development programs under review include the 
5+1 Program and the Liaoning Coastal Economic Belt development plan.7  The 
analysis will identify the extent of ADB assistance to date for Liaoning provincial 
development, and will develop awareness among stakeholders of the need for a 
provincial RCI strategy.  
(ii)  Regional cooperation and integration priorities and models developed for 
Liaoning  Province. This encompasses the delivery of five technical studies 
examining Liaoning’s infrastructure, industrial structure and capacity, financial 
resource requirements, likely sources of investment capital, and domestic and 
international  experience  designing  and  implementing  regional  cooperation 
                                                
7  The provincial government, in its 11th Five Year Plan, 2006–2010, presented the idea in 2005 of the "Five Points 
and One Line" development strategy, in which it is striving to build a coastal economic belt as an economic engine 
for the province. The "Five Points" refers to the areas of Changxing Island Harbor Industrial Zone in Dalian, 
Yingkou Coastal Industrial Base, Liaoxi Jinzhou Bay Coastal Economic Zone, Dandong Industrial Zone, and 
Zhuanghe Huayuankou Industrial Zone in Dalian. The "One Line" refers to a road along the coastal areas, which is 
expected to stimulate growth in the province's coastal economic belt. C. Liu. 2008. “Five Points and One Line” 
Strategy  Remains  Priority.  China  Daily.  14  August.  http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/cndy/2008-
08/14/content_6934201.htm

3 
programs. Needs, opportunities, and requirements associated with realizing and 
benefiting from the PRC’s globalization aspirations in Liaoning Province will be 
presented. The studies will be published as knowledge products, and will target 
key stakeholders such as potential investors, trading partners, and infrastructure 
development managers. The five technical studies developed under the program 
will focus on: 
(a)  problems  associated  with  the  investment  and  financing  of  public 
infrastructure  in  Liaoning  Province  in  the  context  of  the  PRC’s 
globalization strategy, including an examination of how to promote 
construction  of  infrastructure  in  Liaoning  Province  using  a  public–
private partnership model; 
(b)  the policy framework required to support international expansion of 
Liaoning  Province’s  equipment  manufacturing  industry,  which  will 
address reduction of risks facing outward investment, and creation of 
an environment conducive to foreign investment; 
(c)  Liaoning Province’s sea–rail multimodal transportation potential and 
its  fiscal  implications,  including  an  examination  of  key  nodes  and 
relevant policy-based obstacles, and offering a fiscally robust policy 
proposal; 
(d)  seaport  resource  management  in  Liaoning  Province,  including  an 
assessment of provincial seaport capacity, markets and trade flows 
served  (both  domestic  and  international),  infrastructure  asset 
management practices, and the competitive environment within and 
among seaports; and recommendations on how to maximize capacity 
utilization and ensure that regional demand (including that generated 
by  implementation  of  the  Japan–Mongolia  Economic  Partnership 
Agreement) is fully served; and 
(e)  relevant  domestic  and  international  experience  designing  and 
implementing regional cooperation programs, including examination of 
the experience and practices of other countries, and provinces and 
cities in the PRC. This study will examine analogous initiatives such 
as  Russia’s  and  India’s  “North–South  Corridor  Plan”,  the  United 
States’ “New  Silk  Road  Plan”,  and  Japan’s “Silk  Road  Diplomatic 
Strategy.” The experience and practices of other provinces in the PRC 
in  attracting  investment,  managing  infrastructure  assets,  and 
supporting  international  expansion  of  companies  based  in  these 
provinces will be examined to identify good practices. 
(iii)  Regional  cooperation  and  integration  needs  assessment,  development 
strategy, and implementation action plan for Liaoning Province developed. 
The  basis  and  status  of  Liaoning’s  participation  in  the  PRC’s  globalization 
strategy will be analyzed, linking it to efforts to revitalize the northeastern PRC. 
The report will present the framework, basic paths, and policy system needed to 
guide Liaoning’s implementation of the PRC’s globalization strategy, and will 
identify ways ADB can support it.8   
 
9.  Overall, the TA will provide a roadmap for Liaoning Province to maximize RCI benefits in 
the implementation of its obligations under the PRC’s globalization strategy. It will identify 
measures the DOF can take to reduce barriers to interprovincial trade and commerce, and to

broadly in line with the PRC’s globalization strategy.

trade and commerce within Northeast Asia in general. In particular, it will propose initiatives 
specific to Liaoning that can (i) support robust implementation of the World Trade Organization’s 
Trade Facilitation Agreement; and (ii) through proactive engagement with the PRC customs 
service, establish more efficient trade transit in Liaoning.  
 
10.  Stakeholder consultations will be supported by the conduct of an inception workshop 
and a final strategy dissemination and discussion workshop. Workshop discussions will be 
incorporated in the final RCI needs assessment, development strategy, and implementation 
action plan. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
  11.  The TA is estimated to cost $500,000, of which $400,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The government will 
provide counterpart support in the form of workshop and seminar venues; document translation 
and interpretation support for consultant missions, workshops, and seminars; other workshop 
and  seminar  logistics  and  hospitality  arrangements  (e.g.,  office  supplies  and  domestic 
transportation); and other in-kind contributions. The value of the government’s contribution is 
estimated to account for 20% of the total TA cost. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
12.    The Liaoning Provincial DOF will serve as the executing and implementing agency. As 
such,  the  DOF  will  supervise  the  day-to-day  work  of  the  consultants  and  take  overall 
responsibility  for  workshops  and  other  stakeholder  consultations.  The  Public  Management, 
Financial  Sector,  and  Regional  Cooperation  Division  of  ADB’s  East  Asia  Department  will 
administer  and  supervise  TA  implementation.  ADB  will  actively  engage  in  implementation, 
notably through the sharing of knowledge and good practices in the region.  
 
13.    A consulting firm will be recruited to provide a team of international and national experts 
to carry out the proposed studies. The TA will engage (i) three international consultants for a 
total  of  10  person-months,  namely  a  team  leader,  an  economic  policy  analyst,  and  an 
infrastructure finance specialist (focus on transport); and (ii) three to four national consultants for 
a  total  of  24  person-months,  including  a  legal  and  regulatory  expert  and  an  institutional 
development specialist with collective expertise on regional cooperation initiatives in which the 
PRC participates, and an expert in monitoring and evaluation of policy implementation. The 
consultant terms of reference are in Appendix 3. The consultants will be engaged by ADB in 
accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to 
time). The firm will be selected using quality- and cost-based selection procedures (90:10) 
requiring submission of simplified technical proposals.9 
 
14.    The TA will be monitored and evaluated based on the implementation of activities and 
satisfactory delivery of outputs, following the agreed timeline and budget. To support monitoring 
and evaluation, the team leader will submit an inception report and concept note; quarterly 
progress notes; and midterm, draft final, and final reports. TA review missions will provide the 
main mechanism to monitor and assess the TA. The publications created by the TA will be 
provided to the government and ADB for dissemination. The TA outputs, particularly the findings 
and recommendations from the assessments and key studies, will be disseminated through 
                                                
9  TA proceeds will be disbursed in line with  ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as 
amended from time to time). Consultants will be engaged on a lump-sum basis where feasible.

5 
workshops, stakeholder consultations, and publication. The key project deliverables—such as 
the RCI development strategy, five technical studies, and status report and impact assessment 
on  implementation  of  earlier  regional  development  programs  in  Liaoning  Province—will  be 
translated into Chinese.  
 
15.    The TA will commence on 1 March 2016 and be completed on 30 July 2017.    
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
16.   The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for Strategy for Liaoning North Yellow Sea 
Regional Cooperation and Development, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.   The objective of the technical assistance (TA) is to produce a regional cooperation and 
integration (RCI) needs assessment, development strategy, and implementation action plan for 
Liaoning Province. It will include a focus on issues that reduce barriers to interprovincial trade 
and commerce, and to trade and commerce within Northeast Asia generally. It will provide a 
roadmap for Liaoning Province to implement its obligations under national programs such as the 
New Silk Road so that RCI benefits are maximized. 1  
  
2.  The TA will be implemented over a period of 17 months and will require a total of 34 
person-months of consulting services (three international consultants for a total of 10 person-
months and three to four national consultants for a total of 24 person-months). 
 
3.  The  consultants  will  be  responsible  for  producing  the  TA  outputs  and  deliverables 
effectively and on time, consistent with the design and monitoring framework, and for organizing 
and carrying out all TA activities, including workshops and stakeholder consultations. 
 
4.  The  executing  and  implementing  agency—the  Liaoning  Provincial  Department  of 
Finance (DOF)—will coordinate with government authorities and other stakeholders, and assign 
counterpart  staff  to  assist  the  consultants.  The  executing  and  implementing  agency  will 
supervise  the  day-to-day  work  of  the  consultants  and  assume  overall  responsibility  for 
workshops and stakeholder consultations. 
 
5.  The team leader, in cooperation with the DOF and Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
project officer, will oversee, coordinate, and monitor the consultants’ work. Accordingly, the 
consultants will maintain close working relations with the DOF and ADB for their outputs, and 
will regularly discuss project progress and findings. Meetings involving the consultants, the DOF, 
and (as feasible) ADB staff, will be held to provide guidance to the consultants and to review 
their reports. The consultants will help ensure that knowledge products are disseminated (e.g., 
in workshops, stakeholder consultations, and on government and ADB websites), and made 
available to stakeholders. 
 
A.  International Consultants (10 person-months) 
6.  Team leader (4 person-months, intermittent). This position will be assigned ideally to a 
full-time employee of the lead consulting firm, with an advanced degree (doctorate, master’s 
degree, or equivalent) in trade economics, and 15 years or more of experience in leading the 
formulation of regional development strategies for maritime provinces in several countries. The 
team leader should be a trade economist or analyst; have an excellent knowledge of Northeast 
Asia and the World Trade Organization; and have led at least three complex studies of similar 
scope. The team leader must have strong regional trade understanding and experience; have 
demonstrated expertise in comparative regional development through previous assignments; 
and have the capacity to engage in senior policy dialogue and to develop long-term visions and 
perspectives. The team leader will be responsible for ensuring the coherence, complementarity, 
quality, and punctual submission of all deliverables. The team leader will also be responsible for 
conducting a TA inception workshop, a stakeholder consultation and outreach seminar, and for 
presenting the outcome of the assignment at a TA completion workshop.

they  and  other  stakeholders  are  regularly  informed  of  progress  and 
developments in the work; 
(v)  on the basis of the technical studies produced, preparing material suitable for 
publication and for use in other information releases; the material should be in 
Chinese  and  English,  as  appropriate  for  the  intended  audiences,  and  in 
accordance with the needs identified by the executing agency and ADB (all main 
project deliverables will be translated into Chinese); 
(vi)  organizing the workshops and stakeholder consultations with the DOF and other 
relevant stakeholders; 
(vii)  preparing and submitting all TA reports on time, and assisting with TA reviews 
undertaken by the DOF and ADB; and 
(viii)  consulting with development partners working on related activities to inform them 
of  activities  and  to  maintain  a  high  level  of  coordination  in  order  to  avoid 
duplication or overlap of work. 
 
8.   Economic policy analyst (3 person-months, intermittent). The consultant will have an 
advanced degree (doctorate, master’s degree or equivalent qualification) in the economic policy 
of attracting direct foreign investment, or industrial expansion and development; at least 10 
years of experience in the formulation and assessment of regional development strategies; an 
excellent knowledge of trade and investment data sources; and a deep and thorough knowledge 
of the industrial bases of the Northeast People’s Republic of China (PRC) and Northeast Asia, 
their origins, comparative advantages, and future prospects. The consultant will be responsible 
for (i) validating baselines from which to assess the achievement of TA impact; (ii) preparing a 
series of financial and economic studies that will support preparation of the Liaoning RCI needs 
assessment, development strategy, and implementation action plan; (iii) identifying possible 
new markets that may emerge as a direct result of the regional development strategy; and (iv) 
designing,  developing  the  substance  for,  and  conducting  the  workshops  and  stakeholder 
consultations described in 7(iv) above. The consultant will work closely with the team leader and 
infrastructure finance specialist to formulate the regional needs assessment and development 
strategy. Experience will include work in the PRC, although not exclusively. The consultant will 
have conducted at least three assignments similar to this one. Good knowledge of Northeast 
Asia is required. 
 
9.   Infrastructure  finance  specialist  (Transport)  (3  person-months,  intermittent).  The 
consultant will have an advanced degree (doctorate, master’s degree or equivalent qualification)

Appendix 3  11 
in transport economics, civil engineering, or infrastructure costing and financing; at least 10 
years of experience in the development of multimodal infrastructure investment plans in the 
context  of  regional  development  strategies;  thorough  knowledge  of  transport  infrastructure 
assets, their functionality, capacity, and interoperable compatibility in the Northeast PRC and 
Northeast Asia; and intimate familiarity with infrastructure financing alternatives as applied to 
date  in  the  Northeast  PRC  and  Northeast  Asia.  The  consultant  will  be  responsible  for  (i) 
preparing a series of technical studies pertaining to transport infrastructure development and 
financing in Liaoning Province to support regional cooperation and integration; (ii) working 
closely with the DOF to prioritize needs and identify sources of finance (both public and private); 
(iii) ensuring that proposed investments serve the needs of major industries and complement 
existing assets within the region to support expanded trade and increase competitiveness; and 
(iv) proposing operational improvements that will lead to optimal use of existing and future 
transport  infrastructure  assets.  The  consultant  will  work  closely  with  the  team  leader  and 
economic analyst to formulate the Liaoning RCI needs assessment and development strategy. 
Experience will include work in the PRC, although not exclusively. The consultant will have 
conducted at least three assignments similar to this one. Good knowledge of Northeast Asia is 
required. 
 
B.  National Consultants (24 person-months) 
10.  The firm may propose additional positions to be staffed by national consultants and 
determine the length of each consultancy contract based on needs identified at project inception. 
The team of national consultants is expected to include a legal and regulatory expert and an 
institutional development specialist with collective expertise on regional cooperation initiatives in 
which the PRC participates, and an expert in monitoring and evaluation of policy implementation. 
These experts, at a minimum, should each have a university degree and 10 years of experience 
in their respective areas of expertise. The legal and regulatory expert will examine, in particular, 
interprovincial barriers to trade that may (i) artificially limit the volume of transit traffic that 
existing infrastructure capacity could otherwise support, or (ii) introduce delays that compromise 
the predictability of freight delivery. The institutional development specialist will examine the 
roles  and  mandates  of  various  provincial  government  agencies  in  contributing  to  and 
participating in RCI initiatives, describe the involvement of Liaoning Province in various RCI 
initiatives (both domestic and international), and provide an understanding of best practices in 
PRC seaport administration. The policy implementation monitoring specialist will develop a 
methodology  for  monitoring  implementation  of the  Liaoning  Province  regional  development 
strategy and action plan. All national consultants will contribute to preparation of the needs 
assessment,  regional  development  strategy  and  implementation  action  plan,  background 
studies, and organization and conduct of the workshops and seminar. They will work closely 
with  the  international  team  members  to  ensure  the  accuracy  of  all  deliverables  and  data 
underpinning the team’s work. English language skills will be advantageous. 
 
C.  Methodology 
11.  The consultants will implement and deliver the TA in three phases. Phase 1 will examine 
(i)  the  current  status  of  Liaoning’s  implementation  of  previous  regional  cooperation  and 
integration  initiatives,  analyzing  the  extent  to  which  these  initiatives  have  increased  the 
competitiveness of Liaoning’s economy, expanded trade (including transit traffic), and attracted 
inward investment; and (ii) the scope and coverage of ADB assistance to date for development 
of Liaoning Province. In parallel and continuing into the second phase, a compilation of five 
discrete technical studies will be prepared (outlined in para. 12). Phase 2 of the assignment will 
focus  on  identifying,  detailing,  and  disseminating  information  on  opportunities  for  Liaoning

12  Appendix 3 
Province to benefit from a number of initiatives that aim to promote intraregional trade in 
Northeast Asia. This will include the conduct of stakeholder consultations and the development 
of proposals for incorporation in the draft RCI strategy and implementation action plan. Phase 3 
will produce a draft RCI needs assessment, development strategy, and implementation action 
plan for Liaoning Province, based on the research findings and studies conducted under phases 
1 and 2. 
 
12.  Specifically, for phase 1 the consultants will undertake the following: 
(i)  conduct  a  baseline  impact  assessment  and  research  on  (a)  the  scope  and 
coverage of the PRC initiatives to revitalize the Northeast PRC, and (b) the use 
of RCI as a confidence-building measure to increase trade and investment in 
Northeast  Asia,  and  summarize  this  research  in  analytical  reports  on 
intraregional (Northeast Asia) trade and the involvement of Liaoning Province in 
these initiatives; 
(ii)  undertake  field  missions  to  Liaoning  Province  to  collect  relevant  data  and 
information; and hold discussions with officials, corporate managers, experts, 
and other stakeholders in trade, industry, and transport; 
(iii)  submit to the DOF and ADB a concept note on the RCI policy—including details 
about critical issues and proposed scope, coverage, and content—and outline a 
TA delivery schedule, including specific submission dates for each of the five 
discrete technical studies outlined in (v) (below); 
(iv)  conduct a TA inception workshop and capacity development seminar on pursuing 
emerging  opportunities  to  increase  subregional  trade.  The  workshop  will 
summarize phase 1 findings, introduce the TA, and present the initial concept; 
and 
(v)  prepare a series of five discrete technical studies, focusing on:  
(a)  investment and financing problems of public infrastructure of Liaoning 
Province, 
(b)  the  policy  framework  for  supporting  the  international  expansion  of 
Liaoning Province’s equipment manufacturing industry,  
(c)  Liaoning Province’s sea–rail multimodal transportation potential and its 
fiscal implications, 
(d)  seaport resource management of Liaoning Province, and  
(e)  relevant  domestic  and  international  experience  in  designing  and 
implementing regional cooperation programs. 
 
13.   For phase 2 the consultants will: 
(i)  conduct  a  capacity  development  workshop  to  familiarize  stakeholders  with 
opportunities presented by the PRC’s anticipated accession to the Transports 
Internationaux  Routiers  Carnets  Convention,  the  Japan–Mongolia  Economic 
Partnership  Agreement,  and  proactive  implementation  of  the  World  Trade 
Organization Trade Facilitation Agreement; 
(ii)  review and consider national and regional experiences of the process of trade 
liberalization, and identify specific actions that might contribute to revitalization of 
the Northeast PRC; 
(iii)  formulate proposals for strategies, policies, programs, and effective measures 
aimed  at  facilitating  intraregional  trade  and  attracting  inward  investment  into 
Liaoning; and 
(iv)  formulate  proposals  for  a  national  and  regional  (Northeast  Asia)  policy  on 
comprehensive and coordinated approaches to trade that entail improvements in

Appendix 3  13 
infrastructure and provision of efficient and competitive transport infrastructure 
and services. 
 
14.   For phase 3 the consultants will: 
(i)  present  a  draft  RCI  needs  assessment,  development  strategy,  and 
implementation action plan for Liaoning Province to the executing agency and 
ADB  and,  after  incorporating  comments,  in  a  TA  completion  workshop.  The 
workshop  will  serve  to  present,  discuss,  and  revise  the  team’s  preliminary 
findings, proposals and recommendations;2 and 
(ii)  work with the executing agency and ADB to identify materials suitable for broader 
dissemination  as  knowledge  products  (e.g.,  policy-based  briefs,  written  case 
studies assessing international experience, and knowledge showcases for senior 
decision-makers), and revise the identified materials accordingly.3  
 
D.   Reporting Requirements 
 
15.   The team leader for each output will be responsible for ensuring all TA reports meet a 
high professional standard. In addition to the specific reports required for each output, they are 
to produce the reports described below for each output in order to document and assess TA 
activities. These reports are to be written in English. With the support of TA consultants, and 
respecting all confidentiality requirements, the team leader will submit the following: 
(i)  Inception report. A brief report (maximum of five pages plus appendixes) that 
provides a clear plan for implementing the TA, challenges to its success, and a 
summary of the status of TA performance. It will, to the extent feasible, provide (a) 
confirmation  of  the  overall  TA  rationale  and  design;  (b)  adjustments 
recommended to improve TA performance, including to the consultant terms of 
reference; and (c) a TA implementation schedule. 
(ii)  Quarterly progress notes. These brief notes (maximum of three pages) will 
inform the government and ADB of the status of TA implementation. 
(iii)  Midterm report. This report will inform the government and ADB of the status of 
implementing the terms of reference, plans for achieving the TA objectives, and a 
personnel schedule with accomplishments under each item of the design and 
monitoring  framework  (DMF).  This  report  will  record  activities,  outputs,  and 
outcomes directly against the TA DMF. It will provide (a) confirmation of the 
overall TA rationale and design; (b) recommended adjustments to improve TA 
performance, including to the consultant terms of reference; and (c) a detailed TA 
implementation schedule.  
(iv)  Draft final report. This report will (a) summarize TA activities and results by 
reporting against the DMF; and (b) provide recommendations on any additional 
steps required to sustain the results of the TA. 
(v)  Final report. This report will be submitted by the consultants within 1 month of 
receipt of the comments on the draft final report from the government and ADB, 
and will respond to the comments received. 
 
 
                                                
2  Final report will reflect stakeholder comments.

the agreed period.
